rename.from: Upload file to remote from URL
rename.to: Upload file to remote storage from URL

body:
Nice idea!

I think that would be best implemented as a separate command, say

    rclone copyurl https://example.com/file.tar remote:File/file.tar

Yes rclone does need to know the size of files in advance, however for a lot of remotes, you can just use 0 and it will work.  This doesn't work with b2 for instance.  You mostly likely will get a Content-Length as you suggest though.

This is amazing, currently I'm running a VPS from OVH that has only 10gb of disk space (~8gb available for use), this surely will help a lot.

I have a doubt: Will this command work if the file is bigger than the current available disk space? Example:
I'm going to download a 10gb file, but I have only 8gb of available space on disk, is it going to work? Will this mechanism use my RAM memory as a buffer?
+1 this would be awesome, would be even better if you could pass a list of URLs.

I'm dreaming:
Imagine if we could integrate [jdownloader2](https://support.jdownloader.org/Knowledgebase/Article/View/40/0/myjdownloaderorg-api-docu) with rclone?
Something like:
`rclone jd2 http://linkToCloudProvider remote:path`
I know, I know, I'm thinking too much big haha.
I think a URL list and/or the ability to take an open directory and directly send that to a cloud destination would be amazing :)

I'll just note that you might be able to solve this with the [http backend](https://rclone.org/http/).

If the source file(s) are on a webserver with directory listings then you can configure it as an http remote.
+1 for that feature. The hint about the http backend doesn't work for my use case unfortunately.
I understand this ISNT golang, but I think we should all take https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/NoPlusOne into account.
Anyone want to work on the `copyurl` command?  Happy to walk people through what needs to be done?
I can try to work on it @ncw, but my experience is limited (all ive done is setup [this](https://imagen.click) and some tinkering in golang and py.)

@gidoBOSSftw5731 that would be great if you wanted to have a go.

First step get the rclone source (use `go get github.com/ncw/rclone`) then change the origin to point to your fork on github.  Let me know if you need more detail here.  I should probably write some "how to set up a dev environment for rclone" instructions.

What you'll be doing is making a new command.  These are in the `cmd` directory.  You'll need to make a new directory called `copyurl`.  Take a look at the other commands and see what is in a simple one (say `cmd/delete/delete.go`).  Make the new command compile (just get it to print something).  Add the command to `cmd/all/all.go`, compile rclone (go build or go install from the rclone root) and check you have a new command.

That is the first steps.  Next the coding of the actual command...  Use the [net/http](https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/) to make a GET request to the URL in the command line.  This will give you an `http.Response`.  To get things going use `operations.Rcat` to upload the content to the Fs you will parse out of the command line.

I just remembered - we do this already in the `serve restic` command

https://github.com/ncw/rclone/blob/6301e15b793d9e53f3dce67e11bad521358c873e/cmd/serve/restic/restic.go#L333-L369

Probably what we want to do is factor that out into `operations.UploadHttpResponse` (write tests) and call that. It does the more efficient thing if we know the ContentLength.

Anyway that was a bit of a brain dump - let me know if you want more help. Post PRs and I'm happy to comment on them.
@gidoBOSSftw5731 reading the above again, I think what we should do is get your PR as calling `operations.Rcat` then it will work and I'll think about the refactor job!
Sorry for the delay, I'll get to this today hopefully
Out of curiosity, since I assume we would have to save the file for a few moments (to then execute a upload command,) should I use memory? tmpdir?
@gidoBOSSftw5731 No you'd stream the file so no storage required. So you'd pass the `resp.Body` to `operations.Rcat`...
